A. Monetary ExpansionMoney Multiplier. It is fairly easy to find evidence that the monetaryexpansion of the mid— and late—1930s could not have been endogenous. The main
way that the money supply might grow endogenously is through changes in thelending activities of banks. It is usually argued that in response to a boom,banks may raise the deposit to reserve ratio and customers may accept a higherdeposit to currency ratio. Both of these changes Imply that a given supply ofhigh—powered money can then support a larger stock of Ml.
